modernity.label: Modernity and Dress (19th–20th c.)
modernity.short: How industrial modernity reshaped clothing, production, and social meaning.
modernity.extended: Covers the relationship between industrialization, urban life, and the social semiotics of dress in modern societies.
modernity.research: Route via museum research portals (V&A, Met) and university design history programs; prioritize peer-reviewed work on modernity and material culture.

industrialization.label: Industrialization, Mass Production, and Fashion
industrialization.short: Mechanization and new supply chains expanded access and accelerated trend cycles.
industrialization.extended: Discusses garment factories, standardized sizing, retail infrastructures, and the transformation of fashion into an industrial-cultural system.
industrialization.research: Consult institutional archives and economic/social history scholarship on the apparel industry and consumption.

dress_reform.label: Dress Reform and Social Change (late 19th–early 20th c.)
dress_reform.short: Movements critiquing restrictive dress and advocating functional clothing.
dress_reform.extended: Analyzes reform discourse around health, mobility, gender norms, and moral politics of dress.
dress_reform.research: Use museum collections/research essays and academic gender & social history publications.

haute_couture_system.label: The Haute Couture System and Fashion Institutions
haute_couture_system.short: Institutionalization of couture, branding, and seasonal presentation systems.
haute_couture_system.extended: Frames couture as an institutional field involving designers, houses, press, clients, and regulatory bodies shaping legitimacy.
haute_couture_system.research: Route via university archives, museum fashion departments, and scholarly histories of couture institutions.

consumption_distinction.label: Consumption, Distinction, and Taste
consumption_distinction.short: How fashion indexes class and status through taste and cultural capital.
consumption_distinction.extended: Builds on sociological theory of distinction; considers how style operates as a social boundary mechanism.
consumption_distinction.research: Use institutional sociology and cultural studies literature via university libraries.

subculture_style.label: Subculture, Style, and Signification (mid–late 20th c.)
subculture_style.short: Style as symbolic practice within youth cultures and subcultural formations.
subculture_style.extended: Covers how subcultural dress performs identity, opposition, and belonging within broader media systems.
subculture_style.research: Route via academic cultural studies and media studies resources indexed by university libraries.

postmodern_fashion.label: Postmodern Fashion (late 20th c.)
postmodern_fashion.short: Pluralism, pastiche, and quotation reshaping fashion meaning-making.
postmodern_fashion.extended: Engages with fragmentation of authority, remix aesthetics, and semiotic play in fashion representation.
postmodern_fashion.research: Use peer-reviewed cultural theory and museum exhibitions catalogues where available through institutional portals.

gender_performativity.label: Gender, Performativity, and Dress (20th c.)
gender_performativity.short: Dress as a medium through which gender is enacted and negotiated.
gender_performativity.extended: Frames clothing as a site of social regulation and performance; contextualized within 20th-century gender studies.
gender_performativity.research: Route via university gender studies programs and museum research materials; prioritize peer-reviewed scholarship.

global_fashion_system.label: Global Fashion Systems (late 20th c.)
global_fashion_system.short: Globalization of production, branding, and cultural circulation of style.
global_fashion_system.extended: Covers transnational supply chains, media, and the global diffusion of fashion imaginaries.
global_fashion_system.research: Use institutional economic history, anthropology, and global studies sources via academic libraries.

material_culture.label: Material Culture and Textiles
material_culture.short: Textiles and garments as material evidence for social history.
material_culture.extended: Emphasizes methods of object-based research, provenance, and conservation as knowledge practices.
material_culture.research: Route via museum conservation/research departments and university material culture programs.
